description.narrative:
Reach 40,000 individuals to benefit through WASH, Livelihood and Health interventions: 1) Food Security and Livelihood - 225 HHs will be supported with tools (Sickle, hoes, rakes, machete etc). 20 famers groups of 60 members each will get 20 ox ploughs. 280 HHs will be supported with fishing equipment. 150 HHs will get sorghum seeds. 1800 HHs will get maize seeds. 100HHs will get cassava stems. 1800 HHs will get bean seeds. 200 unemployed youths will have improved income from Cash for Work schemes. 100 farming group leaders will have extended training on using ox ploughs. 50 farming group leaders will have extended training on crop production techniques
2) WASH - 3,000 people will have improved access through the rehabilitation of 6 defunct water point. 6,000 people will have improved access to water from 12 newly constructed water points. 18 pumps will be rehabilitated with repairs. 30,000 people reached with hygiene messages using WASH IEC materials (sign Boards, Shirts, Caps, Banners etc). 42 member Water Management Committee will be formed and trained to ensure orderliness and better facility management. At least 1,200 children will practice hand washing using the 12 facilities constructed at the selected school in Terekeka. 1,000 HHs will have benefited from WASH NFIs (Plastic Sheets, Blankets, Mosquito Nets, Sleeping Mats, Jericans, Kitchen sets). 1,500HHs will have improved hygiene due to provision of Laundry Soap. Family Hygiene Kits to be distributedto 560 HHs in IDP camps to improve family sanitation.
3) Primary Health Care- 18,500 people (8000 children, 6500 women and 4000 men) will have access to primary health care through provision of essential medicines and equipment at the targeted 3 PHCC (primary health care centers). 3,000 women will receive improved maternal services at Tarkeka areas of CES (Central Equatoria State). 12,000 people will receive health education at the targeted PHCC. There will be quick referral using the improvised motorcycle ambulances to 3,000 remote villages of Tarkeka and Rokon. 16 medical care workers (6 midwives, 8 nurses, 2 clinical Officers) will be trained on-job in CES. 1,000 HHs will be provided with mosquito nets to be used by children under five years and pregnant women.
To enable vulnerable people in Central Equatoria and Jonglei states to recover from shocks of conflict and loss as they get acquainted in improvised settlements.
